newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: PRESS DIGEST - New Zealand newspapers - June 27.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New Zealand newspapers - June 27.

text.p: THE DOMINION

The Peters plan: a balancing act: Treasurer Winston Peters on Thursday delivered a compromise first Budget, balancing NZ First-inspired social policy spending against keeping a tight grip on the purse strings. Page 1.

Creech sees education's $111m as a down payment: Extra education expenditure of $111 million next year is less than a third of the coalition agreement's $384 million, but Education Minister sees it as a down payment. Page 2.
Underclass not helped -- Anderton: The Budget did nothing to halt the growth on an alienated, improverished underclass, Alliance leader Jim Anderton told Parliament on Thursday. Page 2.
Extra funding gets lukewarm response: Extra money for special education was positive, but overdue, Special Education Consumers' Coalition spokesman Cloan Makgill said on Thursday night. Page 2.

Luxton calls for dairy deregulation: Commerce Minister John Luxton on Thursday mounted his fiercest attack yet on the Dairy Board, calling for the board to be corporatised and lose its export monopoly. Page 13.

Phone billing alternatives to be offered: Telecom is to offer residential customers the choice from August 1 of paying for each local call in return for a lower monthly rental or remain with the present charging system. Page 13.
THE NEW ZEALAND HERALD

Peters bets on growing economy: Package hangs on expectation of 4.2pc rate: The credibility of the coalition government's first budget hangs on a single hook -- the expectation that the economy will grow 4.2 percent in the 1998-99 year.
Promised spending on health falls short: The budget has failed to bring the promised spending boosts to health trumpeted in last year's coalition agreement.

Crusade off over state asset sales: The Treasurer, Winston Peters, has dropped his crusade against privatisation by signposting the sale of two state-owned enterprises -- Government Property Services and Vehicle Testing New Zealand.

$1b payback target: ECNZ has been targeted for a potential $1 billion payback and a raft of state-owned enterprises will be expected to divest non-core businesses as the government moves to boost flagging coffers.
Retailers give thumbs down: Retailers have given Winston Peters' first budget the thumbs down, and say they do not believe his assurance that tax cuts will go ahead as planned enxt year.

Tariff cuts cause fear of recession in car industry: New car assemblers and importers are concerned the government will cause a recession in their industry with a harn-fisted approach to announcing changes in tariffs.
THE PRESS
A failure -- Labour: The Budget is a failure at all levels and proof that Treasurer Winston Peters is not up to the job, Labour says. Page 1.
Ruling soon in power-price row: A decision may be made today or tomorrow on the South Island power price differential, Energy Minister Max Bradford says. Page 1.
Alliance claims Maoris dealth a 'bitter blow': Maoris have been insulted by the Budget, opposition parties say. Page 4.
Lower surpluses surprise markets: Lower-than-expected Budget surpluses caused interest rates to firm on Thursday, while shares and the dollar remained steady. Page 18.
Govt signals readiness to end vehicle tariffs: Zero tariffs on motor vehicles are possible soon after 2000, says Commerce Minister John Luxton. Page 18.
Loophole for funds may be closed: Superannuation funds using index-linked investments to avoid capital gains tax could soon have the loophole closed. Page 18.
